Authors:
johannes alwyn van der linde, Diana L Six, Jolanda Roux,
Michael J Wingfield
Title:
New species of Gondwanamyces from dying Euphorbia trees in
South Africa.
Keywords:
Tree diseases, Cossonus, Custingophora, Euphorbia ingens,
Euphorbia tetragona, Insect-fungus interactions, Knoxdavesia
Abstract:
Gondwanamyces and its Custingophora anamorphs were first
described from Protea infructescences in South Africa. More recently,
these unusual fungi have been found for the first time outside Africa on
Cecropia in South America. During the course of an investigation into
the decline and death of native Euphorbia trees in South Africa, several
fungal isolates resembling the anamorph state of Gondwanamyces were
obtained from diseased tissues. In this study, these isolates are
identified based on morphology and comparisons of DNA sequences. Two
previously unknown Gondwanamyces spp. were identified, one of which was
associated with damage caused by a coleopteran beetle. Inoculation
studies showed that the new Gondwanamyces spp. are pathogenic on
Euphorbia ingens and could contribute to the decline of these
trees.
